lines.text: My wife objects to drinking.
Then she shouldn't drink.
She doesn't.
What's her objection?
Perhaps you can explain the red on this cigarette.
Yes, I... cut my tongue when I was shaving this morning.
Well, bless my blonde heart!
So I'm a ditherer? Well, I'm jolly well going to dither, then!
Oh, George, I can see right through you.
Say, that's funny. I can see through you, too.

[seeing her body lying next to George's beside the car, which has just crashed]
George, look. You know something George? I think we're dead.
I think you're right. Funny; I don't *feel* any different.

[goes to change Topper's flat tire]
Well, I'll be darned if I waste any ectoplasm doing it.
[turns invisible]
I'll be out before you can say Jack Robinson - only don't say it for a few minutes.
Wilkins, after all these years, are you trying to be funny?
Good Morning Mrs. Kerby, if you're looking for your husband...
Oh no, I know where he is, in there dumbing up the director's meeting. But if you should happen to see him looking for someone, remind him that it's me, will you? And tell him where I am?
My pet, resting's the sort of thing you've got to work up to gradually... very dangerous to rest all of a sudden.
30 in the morning?
No, this is Topper's bank.
Good morning, Clara.
Good morning, dear. You're late.
Oh... better late than never. Only 44 seconds, anyhow.
[Topper reading annual report of his bank]
Bullion abroad and in transit, thirteen million, two hundred and two thousand, eight hundred and fifty-four dollars and no cents.
No sense.
I just said that, Mr. Kerby.
So did I.
Why don't you stop being a mummy for a few minutes and come to life? Of course, there's nothing wrong with being a mummy if you had any fun getting that way.
But I... I didn't, you see.
No, I can tell that by the way you're staring at my knees.
Let's go have some dinner.
Oh no, we cannot eat on an empty stomach!
Then we better have a few drinks first!

[to two bewildered onlookers, who've been watching him talk to an invisible Marion]
Well, is it *my* fault there's no one here?

[drunk]
Well, that's how I dance. How do you like it?

[smiles and nods politely]
Yes, I thought that was pretty - bad.
[George and Marion watch a drunk Topper laying on the floor, passed out]
I don't think he's ever had a drink in his life.
Poor Topper.
Poor Topper.

[mutters]
Poor Topper.
You keep out of this.
Can't you even *look* like a human being?
I don't know, sir, I've never tried.
Can't you look where I'm goin'?
Clara, we used to play together once, and we could again. We could drive up to Lake Placid, just you and I. Stop at a roadhouse, dinner, and dance.
Drive in that? You're asking me to drive in a car that looks like a painted Jezebel. And drive it to a roadhouse? Why, it'd be like going to the opera in my night gown!
You have become a legend before your time.
Say, if I'm in the way, you folks could leave.

[she and George Kerby are invisible to Topper]
Toppy doesn't know us, Toppy doesn't know us!

[to George, referring to his wife]
Yes, I'v never - never beaten her.
[awkwardly]
Not... yet, I haven't.
[pauses, then nods to liquor on the table]
Open the other bottle.
What's wrong here?
You are. Take a walk.
Quiet, I'm practicing to be an angel.
Some angel you'd make.

[referring to Topper]
Did you notice something funny about that guy?
That guy ain't funny, he ain't even human!
Say, if I'm in the way, you folks could leave.
Having a little chair trouble, but, don't pay any attention to it.

[speaking to George Kerby about Marian Kerby]
Use your influence. If you haven't any, beat her.
